recipes.Comment: Ordinary Portland cement type CEM-I (full setup for hydration), ReactExtent values given for 28 days of hydration at 20 C and w/b ratio 0.4.

materials.Comment: Portland cement via mineral composition [Lothenbach, B., Le Saout, G., Gallucci, E., Scrivener, K. (2008), Cement and Concrete Research, 38(6), 848-860], real compositions of clinker constituents from [Taylor (1989), Advances in Cement Research, 2(6), 73-77, Table 1]

constituents.Comment: Tricalcium silicate C3S (alite), real composition from [Taylor (1989), Advances in Cement Research, 2(6), 73-77, Table 1]
Dicalcium silicate C2S (belite), real composition from [Taylor (1989), Advances in Cement Research, 2(6), 73-77, Table 1]
Tricalcium aluminate C3A (aluminate cubic), real composition from [Taylor (1989), Advances in Cement Research, 2(6), 73-77, Table 1]
Tetracalcium aluminoferrite C4AF, real composition from [Taylor (1989),  Advances in Cement Research, 2(6), 73-77, Table 1]
Magnesium oxide (periclase), ideal stoichiometry, reaction extent as of belite
Limestone powder, real composition from [De Weerdt et al. (2011), Cement and Concrete Research, 41, 279-291, Table 1]
Silica fume, real composition from [Olsson et al. (2018), Cement and Concrete Research, 108, 31-37], Table 2.
Ground granulated blast furnace slag, real composition from [Savastano et al. (2005), Cement and Concrete Composites, 27, 583-592, Table 1], insoluble residue as TiO2, LoI as H2O

Calcined clay (metakaolin), real composition from [Avet, F., Li, X., Scrivener, K. (2018), Cement and Concrete Research, 106, 40-48], Table 1 col.1 (94.2% metakaolin Al4.5Si1.5O9.75, 4.6% mullite), LoI as H2O, Others as CaO

Coal fly ash (reactive) amorphous, C(free) removed, from [De Weerdt, K., Ben Haha, M., Le Saot, G., Kjellsen, K., Justness, H., Lothenbach, B. (2011), Cement and Concrete Research, 41 (3), 279-291] Table 1

Pozzolana (Bacoli), real composition from [Massazza, F. (1998). Pozzolana and Pozzolanic Cements. Ch. 10 in Lea's Chemistry of Cement and Concrete (Fourth Edition), Ed. Hewlett, P., Butterworth-Heinemann, p.471-635]

materials.Comment: Water (to mix with cement for hydration)

constituents.Comment: Electrolytes to be added to Lab-water

materials.Comment: CO2, sea salt and other salts for modeling ingress into cement, not represented in SCM and Water materials

results.Comment: Ordinary Portland cement type CEM-I (full setup for hydration), ReactExtent values given for 28 days of hydration at 20 C and w/b ratio 0.4., hydrated

equilibrated.Comment: Ordinary Portland cement type CEM-I (full setup for hydration), ReactExtent values given for 28 days of hydration at 20 C and w/b ratio 0.4., hydrated

residual.Comment: Ordinary Portland cement type CEM-I (full setup for hydration), ReactExtent values given for 28 days of hydration at 20 C and w/b ratio 0.4. - residual part

materials.Comment: Portland cement via mineral composition [Lothenbach, B., Le Saout, G., Gallucci, E., Scrivener, K. (2008), Cement and Concrete Research, 38(6), 848-860], real compositions of clinker constituents from [Taylor (1989), Advances in Cement Research, 2(6), 73-77, Table 1]

constituents.Comment: Tricalcium silicate C3S (alite), real composition from [Taylor (1989), Advances in Cement Research, 2(6), 73-77, Table 1]
Dicalcium silicate C2S (belite), real composition from [Taylor (1989), Advances in Cement Research, 2(6), 73-77, Table 1]
Tricalcium aluminate C3A (aluminate cubic), real composition from [Taylor (1989), Advances in Cement Research, 2(6), 73-77, Table 1]
Tetracalcium aluminoferrite C4AF, real composition from [Taylor (1989),  Advances in Cement Research, 2(6), 73-77, Table 1]
Magnesium oxide (periclase), ideal stoichiometry, reaction extent as of belite
